prior_works.title: Maxout Networks
prior_works.authors: Ian J. Goodfellow, David Warde-Farley, Mehdi Mirza, Aaron Courville, Yoshua Bengio
prior_works.role: Architecture/baseline and upper bounds for max-of-affine representations
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The paper’s discussion of rank-k maxout layers and the non-tightness of a natural upper-bound generalization directly builds on the maxout formulation of maxima of affine functions introduced by Goodfellow et al., informing both the construction of max circuits and the comparison between rank-2 versus mixed-rank (e.g., rank-3 followed by rank-2) layers.

prior_works.title: On the Number of Linear Regions of Deep Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Guido F. Montúfar, Razvan Pascanu, Kyunghyun Cho, Yoshua Bengio
prior_works.relationship_sentence: By casting ReLU networks as inducing polyhedral complexes via hyperplane arrangements and quantifying linear regions, this work provides the polyhedral and combinatorial lens that the present paper sharpens by restricting to compatibility with the braid fan and deriving depth lower bounds for computing max.

prior_works.title: Bounding and Counting Linear Regions of Deep Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Thiago Serra, Christian Tjandraatmadja, Srikumar Ramalingam
prior_works.role: Exact/algorithmic polyhedral analysis of ReLU partitions
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Serra et al.’s framework for bounding and exactly counting linear regions via mixed-integer formulations underpins the paper’s shift from computational verification in small cases to a purely combinatorial proof (e.g., for max of 5), within a structured fan (braid) compatibility assumption.

prior_works.title: Tropical Geometry of Deep Neural Networks
prior_works.authors: Ruihang Zhang, Shengjia Naitzat, Lek-Heng Lim
prior_works.role: Algebraic–geometric foundation linking DNNs to max-plus and fans
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The tropical viewpoint that deep ReLU/maxout networks compute (differences of) max-affine forms and induce normal fans connects directly to the braid fan used here, enabling the paper’s fan-compatibility framework and its combinatorial depth lower bounds for the max function.

prior_works.title: Benefits of Depth in Neural Networks
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Telgarsky’s depth-separation paradigm for ReLU networks motivates the search for lower bounds tied to combinatorial complexity; the present paper adapts this spirit within the braid-arrangement-compatible class to prove a non-constant Ω(log log d) depth requirement for exact max.

prior_works.title: An O(n log n) Sorting Network
prior_works.authors: Miklós Ajtai, János Komlós, Endre Szemerédi
prior_works.role: Comparator/sorting depth as a structural proxy for maxima over braid cones
prior_works.relationship_sentence: The geometry of comparisons underlying sorting networks aligns with the braid arrangement (hyperplanes x_i = x_j), and provides an upper-bound/compositional template for computing maxima that the paper contrasts against by proving new lower bounds under braid-fan compatibility.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core advance—non-constant depth lower bounds for exactly computing max under braid-fan compatibility and a combinatorial proof for the five-variable case—sits at the intersection of polyhedral geometry, tropical algebra, and depth-separation theory. Foundationally, Montúfar et al. established that ReLU networks induce polyhedral partitions governed by hyperplane arrangements, while Serra et al. refined this into tools for bounding and exactly counting linear regions, seeding the methodological shift from brute-force verification to principled combinatorics. Zhang–Naitzat–Lim’s tropical perspective further crystallized deep networks as max-plus (or differences of max) operators whose induced fans reflect the combinatorial structure of the underlying polytopes; this directly motivates the paper’s focus on compatibility with the braid fan—the normal fan of the permutahedron associated with coordinate orderings.
Depth arguments are informed by Telgarsky’s depth-separation program for piecewise-linear networks, but are specialized here to the braid arrangement to yield an Ω(log log d) lower bound for exact max, thereby going beyond the previously flat lower bound of two layers in the unrestricted case. On the constructive side, Goodfellow et al.’s maxout units supply canonical architectures for implementing maxima, and the paper leverages this to show that a seemingly natural upper-bound generalization is not tight, e.g., by exhibiting improved mixed-rank (rank-3 then rank-2) constructions. Finally, classical sorting network theory (Ajtai–Komlós–Szemerédi) provides a comparator-based blueprint aligned with braid cones, serving as a structural comparator for the new lower and upper bounds in this permutation-fan setting.
